content: "Elements of Folk Psychology" is a book written by Wilhelm Wundt and first published in 1879. It is considered one of the foundational works in the field of social psychology. In this book, Wundt argues that the study of psychology must be grounded in the study of culture and society. He asserts that human behavior and mental processes are shaped by the social and cultural contexts in which they occur, and that language is a key factor in this process. Wundt proposes that the meanings of words and concepts are learned through socialization, and that the study of language and culture is essential to understanding human psychology.
